The Dow Chemical Company

Union Carbide Texas City Operations

EPA ID# 1000 0013 5631



Risk Management Plan Five-Year Update 

Executive Summary



Description of the Facility and Purpose of Submittal

 

Union Carbide Texas City Operations is a manufacturing facility that annually produces more than 

five (5) billion pounds of chemicals and plastics including hydrocarbons, specialty polymers, 

solvents, intermediates, monomers and industrial products.  In accordance with U.S. EPA 

regulation 40 CFR 68, the U.S. EPA has identified quantities for 140 toxic or flammable 

substances that require a facility to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule when 

unit inventories exceed threshold quantities.  The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit 

inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA 

approved chemical release prevention program.  In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP 

covered facilities to update its Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) every five (5) years or six (6) 

months after an RMP reportable incident.  Union Carbide Texas City Operations initially 

submitted its RMPlan in June 1999.  In compliance with 40 CFR 68, Union Carbide Texas City 

Operations is submitting the five (5) year update to its initial RMPlan submittal.

Since Union Carbide Texas City Operation's initial submittal in June 1999, Units 81 (OXO) and 82 

(FARM) have reduced RMP chemical inventories to below threshold quantities.  As a result, these 

units have been removed from the current RMPlan.  In addition, Unit 85 (#3 Olefins) has been 

decommissioned and the majority of chemical inventories have been reduced below the 

thresholds, resulting in the removal of those inventories from the RMPlan.



Union Carbide Texas City Operations currently holds the following RMP-regulated substances 

above threshold quantities:



Ethyl ether - CAS No. 60-29-7    

2-Methylpropene - CAS No. 115-11-7

Isopropyl chloroformate - CAS N

o. 108-23-6

Propane - CAS No. 74-98-6

Propylene - CAS No. 115-07-1

Vinyl Acetate Monomer - CAS No. 108-05-4

Vinyl chloride - CAS No. 75-01-4





Key Offsite Consequence Analysis 



40 CFR 68 requires all facilities subject to the rule to conduct an offsite consequence analysis 

and to provide information about any potential consequences of an accidental chemical release to 

the public and state and federal environmental agencies.  Offsite consequence analyses are 

essential in identifying potential hazards of accidental releases.  The offsite consequence 

analysis (OCA) comprises 2 elements, a worst case scenario and an alternative release scenario.





Worst Case Scenarios



Offsite consequence analyses for the worst-case scenarios (WCS) were conducted using the 

Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines.  The 

RMP sets forth specific criteria that must be incorporated in modeling the worst-case scenarios.  

The EPA defines a WCS as one that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a 

specified endpoint.  As defined by the rule, the endpoint for a toxic substance is a specified 

concentration, while for flammables it is a specified overpressure from a vapor cloud explosion 

(VCE).



The scenarios for Union Carbide Texas City Operations were calculated using the EPA OCA 

Look Up Tables.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and 

manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures 

was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios.  



Alternative Release Scenarios



Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) assess the potential hazards that are more realistic than 

worst-case scenarios and are designed to assist in the development of emergency response 

plans.  EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines were used in modeling the 

alternative release scenarios.  As required, alternative release scenarios

are created for both 

toxics and flammables.  These scenarios were calculated using the EPA OCA Look Up Tables.  

Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such 

consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into 

account in evaluating these scenarios.



Five-Year Accident History



Union Carbide Texas City Operations, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical 

releases that resulted in any known off-site deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or 

sheltering in place.  

U.S. EPA Regulation 40 CFR 68.168 requires the following incidents, with respect to on-site 

injuries or damage, to be reported as part of the Risk Management Plan.   The following injuries 

occurred while in the presence of a RMP covered substance.



09/13/2002 - Process Unit VA5 - A contract employee bumped into an open drain valve in a 

tagged-out line which resulted in a category IV LOPC (Loss of Primary Containment) and an 

exposure of vinyl acetate to the employee.  Employee was checked out and cleared to return to 

work.   Amount released estimated 10 Lbs.



01/08/2004 - Process Unit VA5 - While in the process of unloading material into a temporary 

tank, a contract employee was sprayed with vinyl acetate on the left side of his face and clothes.  

Employee was administered first aid.  Estimated chemical release was 560 Lbs.







Accidental Release Prevention Policies



Union Carbide Texas City Operations is committed to operate and maintain its facility in a safe 

and environmentally friendly manner.  Texas City Operations incorporates Dow Chemical's 

Global Management Systems and Emergency Response Plan with the rules and regulations set 

forth by the U.S. EPA Risk Management Plan and OSHA's Process Safety Management Program 

to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings.

Union Carbide Texas City Operations designed its accident prevention progra

m to comply with 

both the EPA RMP rule and with OSHA's Process Safety Management.  Union Carbide 

incorporates the Dow Chemical Operating Discipline Management Systems (ODMS), which 

globalize all Dow facilities with the same environmental, health, and safety regulations.  Included 

in Dow's ODMS are elements addressing the following:



-    Equipment Design - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are 

    designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

-    Process Safety Information - Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is 

    documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.

-    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - PHAs are conducted every three years to identify major 

    process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their 

    occurrence.

-    Episodic Risk Management - Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards which could 

    have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their 

    occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques.

-    Operational Safety Standards - Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls 

    used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards.

-    Operating Procedures - Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process 

    and are maintained up-to-date.

-    Operator Training/Certification Program - The plant has a training and testing program which 

    provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently 

    operate a process.

-    Technical Staff Training and Support - Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a 

    day to support operations.

-    Maintenance Procedures - The plant has specific procedures for maintaining process equipment 

    so that it operates safely.

-    Maintenance Training - The pl

ant trains persons who perform routine or complex maintenance 

    tasks on process equipment.

-    Mechanical Integrity Program - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process 

    equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process 

    equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

-    Management of Change (MOC) - The plant has a management system to ensure that modified 

    facilities and processes will be safe to operate.

-    Pre-startup Safety Review - Reviews are conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified 

    facilities and processes are safe for operation.

-    Incident Investigation - The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents are 

    properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) that are 

    needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.

-    Employee Participation - The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention program 

    elements.

-    Hot Work Permit - The plant has a procedure to ensure that welding, cutting, and brazing are 

    safely performed in areas where flammable or combustible material may be present.

-    Contractor Safety Program - The plant has a procedure to ensure that contractors are properly 

    trained and perform their work in compliance with safety requirements.

-    Compliance Audits - Periodic corporate and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that 

    process operations comply with governmental and corporate requirements.

-    Operational Safety Program - Union Carbide has a comprehrensive program to ensure that all 

    the elements listed are implemented at every Union Carbide location.  This program includes 

    accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements.



These general prevention elements are parts of an overall management system to prevent 

accidental chemical releases.  Union Carbide and its employees are committed to the standards 

that these mana

gement systems set and have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure 

that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.



Emergency Response Program



Union Carbide Texas City Operations maintains a written emergency response program to 

protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of 

procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including fire or explosion, and 

is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the facility. 

The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including:



- Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures.

- Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation.

- Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

- Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.

- Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.



Union Carbide Texas City Operations maintains a trained emergency squad to handle fire, 

explosions, toxic vapor releases, spills, and medical emergencies.  The facility trains and drills 

with local emergency responders to enhance their skills and tactics for responding to an 

accidental chemical release.  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.  

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively 

protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed 

emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Texas City/La Marque Local 

Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Union Carbide Texas City Operations continually strives to improve its safety-related systems.  

Dow Chemical's Management Systems (ODMS) has globalized its policies and procedures to 

provide each facility with the most-improved and efficient means to minimize environmental 

impacts on-site and to the public.  Union

Carbide Texas City Operations also continues to 

improve by implementing an incident investigation database known as GIRD (Global Incident 

Reporting Database) to monitor potential risks of future incidents.  These improvements, along 

with monthly reviews of current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents.
